dialogues.LINCOLN:
[1]What? No bacon? 
[2]Whatever. 
[3]Hello , stranger. 
[4]It's just an expression, that's all. 
[5]Okay, Ester. Where have you been? 
[6]Exciting. 
[7]Us? 
[8]Then you leave all this behind, huh? 
[9]I'll miss your coffee. C'mon, I already burned up my quota. 
[10]That's easy for you to say. Your time's guaranteed. All you have is six months. 
[11]Give me some more of your coffee. 
[12]Hudson Four-Alpha; profile reviewed. Match to vacancy; 171, Sector 5. Request clearance to populate. 
[13]No. 
[14]Six months? 
[15]Census File: Two-Delta, Starkweather. 
[16]He got lucky, that's all. 
[17]Shut up, Jonesy. 
[18]You're out of my weight-class. 
[19]I'll think about it. 
[20]Whoooooo! 
[21]You're just too slow, Jonesy. 
[22]Hey, you put up, now pay up. 
[23]Shut up, Jonesy. 
[24]I can't. I got an interact. 
[25]Hey, it's an authorized interaction. We're on the same meditation program. 
[26]No law against friendship, Jonesy. 
[27]What happened? You lost count? 
[28]Vita Cola all the way, officer. 
[29]Accept. 
[30]I guess I overslept. 
[31]Right. I'll be there. 
[32]Just juice today. I'm late for work. 
[33]C'mon, Kleinwort... 
[34]So what's up with the Censors, huh? 
[35]I know what it is. I've just never seen them out in this sector before. 
[36]What are you saying? They lost someone? 
[37]Census File: Two-Delta, Starkweather. 
[38]Accomodation Status : 102, Sector 4. 
[39]Hey , Jonesy. Remember the guy who won The Spin yesterday? His apartment's still showing as occupied. 
[40]So you get 24 hours to move out. 
[41]No. It updates on the hour. If he's gone it should be showing a vacancy. 
[42]I don't know. He wasn't there to step up. And now there's a census check... 
[43]Maybe. 
[44]Sanitation Status: 102, Sector Four. 
[45]Still in the electrical phase, sir. 
[46]I'll take care of it. 
[47]I said I can't hear you. 
[48]How are you doing, Mac? 
[49]We l l the guys upstairs are griping about the backlog. They want to know when you'll be ready for move in. 
[50]I'll tell them two weeks. 
[51]So . . . got any stuff on you today? 
[52]I t ' s too bad. 
[53]T h a t your shift's almost over. 
[54]The y taste good. 
[55]I like coming here. Talking. Most outsiders don't like to talk. 
[56]What do you do when the shift's over? 
[57]H u m p `n dump crew? 
[58]Is it as bad as they say out there? 
[59]The air... the containments. 
[60]But not everywhere. Not on The Island. 
[61]You wanted to see me? 
[62]I guess not. 
[63]I f I'm here. 
[64]Right. 
[65]Why wouldn't I? 
[66]Ah. 
[67]A r e you saying I'm contaminated? 
[68]The n what's the problem? 
[69]Why? 
[70]No. 
[71]Disrupted? 
[72]I don't know. 
[73]I don't know. 
[74]I don't know. 
[75]That's it. 
[76]Right. 
[77]Now... 
[78]I already burned up my quotas. 
[79]Is that it? 
[80]The r e ' s no law against friendship. 
[81]I know the rules of proximity. 
[82]Thank you. I feel much better now. 
[83]S o r r y I'm late. 
[84]I have to cancel, Ester. 
[85]I don't think so. 
[86]No. 
[87]I want some bacon. 
[88]An d coffee. I want coffee. 
[89]This isn't what I asked for. 
[90]P u t that on my fucking r e c o r d . 
[91]Hello? 
[92]W h o are you? What's wrong with you? 
[93]Ester . . . I have to talk to you. 
[94]What are you talking about? 
[95]I want you to meet me as soon as you can. But you can't tell anyone. 
[96]You know where to come. 
[97]Jonesy. . . 
[98]I saw what happened to him. 
[99]Starkweather . . . What they did to him. 
[100]They cut him open, Jonesy. The y took him upstairs and they cut him open. 
[101]J o n e s y , listen to me... 
[102]Ester, I'm not contaminated. 
[103]I'm not contaminated! 
[104]Contaminants, pathogens... it's just what they tell us to keep us inside. 
[105]I saw it. Why they keep us here. To use us. To take things from us. 
[106]Your baby... they're going to take your baby away... you understand? 
[107]I don't know! But I saw it! 
[108]You can't go back! Don't you get it? 
[109]
[110]Ester ! Come on! 
[111]Ester ! We have to keep going! 
[112]Ester? 
[113]The r e is no green. The windows in there... they were just pictures. 
[114]I think I've found a path. 
[115]My friend... she needs water. 
[116]Away. 
[117]" O u t of state"... 
[118]I'm going to check on my friend. 
[119]What are you doing? 
[120]" O u t of state" - how do I get there? 
[121]I t ' s going to be okay, Ester. 
[122]We just need to get out of state. 
[123]I told you to stay with me. 
[124]O k a y . Okay... 
[125]What are my options? 
[126]I asked the man how to get to the terminal. He said it's not far. 
[127]Now... 
[128]O u t of state. 
[129]We want to go out of state. 
[130]What do you want? 
[131]We have to keep going. 
[132]T h o s e men - that's what they want too. 
[133]We have to keep going, Ester. 
[134]Transport... 
[135]I want to get out of state. Now. 
[136]O u t of state... 
[137]Where's that? 
[138]N o . With her. 
[139]A r e you alright? 
[140]O k a y . . . I'll get you some water. 
[141]Behind you. 
[142]I ' l l find you some water. 
[143]I t ' s going to be okay, Ester. 
[144]I ' l l find you some water, okay? 
[145]I ' l l find another way. Out of state. 
[146]The n we'll keep going. 
[147]We ' l l keep going till we get there. 
[148]N o w I'm going to get some water. But I want you to stay here. It'll be safer. 
[149]The man, the man up there. Who is he? 
[150]The juggernaut... 
[151]Residential... 
[152]Starkweather... 
[153]I don't know. Something. Just wait there and make sure nobody's coming. 
[154]Who are you? 
[155]Who? 
[156]What people? 
[157]I want to know... 
[158]The policy? 
[159]About what? 
[160]What are you talking about? 
[161]What is that? 
[162]What does that mean? 
[163]Why? 
[164]Why do I look like you? 
[165]I don't understand. 
[166]Made me? 
[167]You . . . you're the one who made me? 
[168]Who made me? 
[169]There are men out there, looking for us. I want you to make them stop. 
[170]Do you have transport? 
[171]And then you'll call security? 
[172]Auto... 
[173]O u t of state... West... 
[174]I was looking for water. 
[175]My transport... it stopped working. 
[176]Out of state... 
[177]What is this place? 
[178]A r e you alright? 
[179]The man out there... he said everything has a spirit... every living thing... but not... 
[180]Don't worry. The one we want goes the other way. He said it goes slower. 
[181]Ester! Stop! It's no use! 
[182]It's going too fast! 
[183]What did you give her? 
[184]S o you know about the baby... 
[185]I found your name in the listings. I wasn't sure. You don't look like her. 
[186]S o you're the one who takes her baby. 
[187]Lincoln . My name's Lincoln. 
[188]N o . They'll find her. They'll take her. 
[189]You don't understand. They don't want people to know about her. Either of us. 
[190]Why ? So you can take her baby? 
[191]The y make you believe there's a place called The Island. Then they take you upstairs and put you to sleep. They cut you open. They take pieces of you. 
[192]N o . I saw a lot of us go to The Island. But I never saw anyone come back. 
[193]Is it? I wouldn't know. 
[194]C a n you help her? 
[195]I don't understand any of this. 
[196]He l l o , stranger. 
[197]Ester... 
[198]What do you mean? 
[199]I know. 
[200]No... 
[201]We have to go. We have to get her out. 
[202]He's come for her. For us. 
[203]How long before she wakes up? 
[204]You'll take care of it, won't you? Take her somewhere they can't find her... 
[205]I can't find my sunglasses. I think I left them on the shuttle. 
[206]Don't worry. I'll catch up. 
[207]I t ' s been a year since the breakout. A year in hiding, waiting for things to quiet down. I don't know how many made i t out or how many who did, survived. I know there are people called politicians trying to say it never happened. That's why I've kept this journal. To keep the truth alive. Alive... I've learned what that means but it still confuses me. In functional terms, I've been alive for ten years. In human terms, more than thirty. Human... I'm not sure about that one either. They say I'm not human because I have no mother or father. I guess I have more to learn. But one word I do understand is hope. So maybe this j o u r n a l will give hope - to those like me, who may be out there. To know t h e y ' r e not alone. My name is Lincoln S i x - E c h o and this is my testament... 
[208]Lincoln Junior, huh? It still doesn't sound right. That name. 
[209]We should finish packing. 
[210]Time to go. 
[211]You'll make sure this gets out? 
[212]Thank you, Katherine. For everything. 
[213]I've been looking at them for months. 
[214]I don't need them either.
dialogues.MERRICK:
[1]Good morning. To everyone here and everyone watching on etherscreen, welcome to the community address. Today I'm coming to you from Sector Four. For those of you here with sugar quotas, let me recommend the french toast. I just tried some and it's excellent, really. But I know what everyone's hungry for s o let's move on to the lottery. As always the draw will be made from our host sector. So tell me, Sector Four - is everyone ready for The Daily Spin? 
[2]Let The Spin begin. 
[3]Starkweather Two-Delta! Step up! 
[4]Well , Starkweather, if you're watching on etherscreen - your time has come, my friend! You're moving out to The Island! And the rest of you, never lose hope; what do we know about The Daily Spin? 
[5]An d tomorrow it could be you... 
[6]Yes . Please, take a seat. 
[7]How ' s Lincoln Six-Echo today? 
[8]E v e r y t h i n g going okay? 
[9]Why do you say that? 
[10]I'm not sure I deserve such a negative association. My job's only to see that you're happy. That everything's okay. 
[11]I t sounds like you don't believe me. 
[12]I t ' s part of your makeup. To challenge things. To question what's around you. 
[13]P e r h a p s you can utilize that facility by helping me solve a little puzzle. 
[14]You're doing well in most areas - pro- f i c i e n t a t work, exercising rigorously, your last medical puts you in excellent condition. But screening's picked up some deviations. Trace levels, changes in your sleep pattern... I see you've also been burning up your quotas... 
[15]No. 
[16]The r e are parameters, Lincoln. When someone starts straying from those parameters, we need to find out why. 
[17]Because you - not just you, all of our residents - are special. Because people like me don't get to go to The Island. 
[18]S o tell me, have you noticed any changes in yourself? 
[19]What about your sleep pattern? You feel you've been sleeping properly? 
[20]L e t me put it another way, when you wake up, do you feel... disrupted? 
[21]R e s t l e s s , disoriented, uneasy... 
[22]They're all words in your vocabulary. I know you understand what they mean. 
[23]Quotas . . . nutrition. Do you feel like you want more than you're given? 
[24]Do you have any difficulty staying focused? At work, for instance? 
[25]H a v e you been experiencing feelings, sensations you don't quite understand? 
[26]Do you sometimes feel agitated for no apparent reason? Frustrated, angry... 
[27]An g r y ? You feel angry? 
[28]When exactly do you feel angry? 
[29]I'm going to order some tests at The Medical Center. In the meantime, I'd like you to stay away from stimulants - protein, sugar, caffeine... 
[30]But I know you can get around them. 
[31]I'm asking you to cooperate. Not for my sake, Lincoln, but for your own. 
[32]The r e is one other thing. You have a female friend. "Ester". Your file shows you've been interacting regularly. 
[33]O f course not. We encourage interaction in the hope it'll be of mutual benefit. But given these deviations... let's just say proximity becomes an issue. 
[34]The rules of proximity apply to sexual contact, Lincoln. In this case it goes deeper than that. Ester is entering h e r second trimester. A time of change and emotional confusion. Further inter- a c t i o n might be... unhealthy for you. 
[35]An d for Ester - well, she has only six months left to delivery. Then she'll move out to The Island and whatever ties she has here will be broken. 
[36]A s a friend, shouldn't you make her t r a n s i t i o n as painless as possible? 
[37]G o o d . Now I'm also going to refill your pleasure quota. It may help to settle you down a little. 
[38]I'm not sure you do. But I think you'll do what's right, Lincoln. You may not trust me. But I trust you. 
[39]K a r l . . . Welcome back. 
[40]J u s t a histamine reflex. Your system's readjusting to the sterile environment. 
[41]Yes , well I cut short your leave for a reason. I take it you've been briefed? 
[42]His name is Starkweather Two-Delta. He dropped off the ether two days ago. At first we thought it was a system error. Then we found this in a garbage chute. 
[43]That's right. 
[44]T h a t was entirely different. The product suffered a head injury. 
[45]We don't know. He just disappeared. 
[46]He's a code two, Karl. A low functioner. 
[47]The y don't function mentally, they don't function physically - you know that. 
[48]I f you bothered to read the clone laws, you'd realize we have no choice in the matter. The virtual humanity statutes accord them a set of freedoms. All we can do is prescribe the limits. And even those are subject to regulation. Scope of knowledge, range of activity, even their speech patterns. The law requires that what is of human origin be provided with human characteristics. 
[49]The ether shows no attempts on the boundary. He's here, Karl. But for some reason, your men seem unable to find him. It's your job to contain the products. I'd like you to do it, okay? 
[50]J u s t after Starkweather went missing, his sponsor placed an order. An order we can't fill. Damn right I'm sensitive. 
[51]J a m i l Starkweather . . . last week he sustained a hepatic trauma resulting in liver hemorrhage. In medical terms, we have maybe a few weeks. In legal terms, we're already o n borrowed time... An d Karl? 
[52]I don't want a godawful m e s s like the l a s t time. Minimal damage. Understood? 
[53]There's nothing going on, Karl. 
[54]What's your point? 
[55]You're jumping to conclusions. 
[56]Q u a l i t y control is not your concern. 
[57]That's not what I said. 
[58]It's not an exact science - biogenesis. There's a degree of trial and error. If the agnate doesn't come together on the first pass, we have to abort and start over. It's like breaking inertia. The bioreactor, the growth medium - we just keep upping the levels till we achieve integration. At which stage the agnate is deemed physically stable. We rely on foundation to provide mental stability - matching the templates to their capacity but walling it in with parameters. When signs of instability started to show up, it pointed to foundation. A hole in the wall, an oversight. But it was only happening in the later generat- ions . Which pointed back to biogenesis. 
[59]Actually the opposite. We found out in the later generations, the levels were so high that when we broke inertia, the process kept going. Over-integrating. Specifically the neural system. It produced a condition called synesthesia. 
[60]A fusion of the senses, creating a component awareness. Sixth sense, s e c o n d sight, whatever you want to call it. Its emergence seems to be arbitrary. But it gives them experiences beyond their functional parameters. And ultimately... it destabilizes them. However, if we catch it early enough we can control it with re-conditioning. 
[61]You find this amusing? 
[62]Poetic? 
[63]This stays between you and me, Karl. I trust I can rely on your cooperation? 
[64]Remind me, why is it you were discharged from the military? 
[65]Learn to be a team player, Karl. Or you'll find yourself out of another job. 
[66]Thank you for coming out here. 
[67]First, let me stress there's no way we could have anticipated what happened... 
[68]We'v e lost two of our products. They escaped containment last night. 
[69]We'r e still piecing it together. 
[70]To answer your question, we condition our products with a deterrent. A fear of contamination. And thereby of the outer environment. So to escape, they first have to escape their conditioning. 
[71]
[72]
[73]
[74]
[75]Well . . . the male, we could cover. Fast- track another generation before the sponsor ever needed access. The female comes under the maternity plan. She's three months pregnant. Even if we fast- tracked another generation, we couldn't fast-track the pregnancy. We'd miss the delivery date, the sponsor would wonder why and there would be... difficulties. 
[76]I just don't think we should under- estimate them. Especially the male. 
[77]Bad news. 
[78]The male agnate tracked him down. 
[79]I told her, Henry. About synesthesia. 
[80]We had no choice, Karl. We had to keep this away from The Institute. 
[81]Your resignation papers. Maybe `early retirement' would be more accurate... 
[82]T e n platinum bounty - if you sign the papers, their loss becomes your gain. 
[83]You understand that whatever happens, The Institute must be able to deny it. 
[84]We use a chemical to dispose of waste product. It's called di-halcyonate. I t reacts on a molecular level to start a process of internal combustion. The subject is incinerated from the inside out. In post-mortem application it's done its job before rigor mortis. In a live subject, well... you can imagine. 
[85]I t ' s a little more complicated than that. We have to be very... thorough. If you still have it in you, that is. 
[86]I don't know. 
[87]S o you wear it is a badge of honor? 
[88]You'll find a vehicle parked outside. It's unregistered, difficult to trace. I take it we have an agreement...? 
[89]An d it's a terrible loss. 
[90]E t h e r c o n ! Ether control, come in! 
[91]An y o n e ! Somebody pick up! 
[92]How wide is this going?
dialogues.ESTER:
[1]Lincoln ! Over here! 
[2]What? You don't recognize me? 
[3]You and your expressions, Lincoln. Now sit down and ask me where I've been. 
[4]At the medical center. Just for tests but they had me on liquid nutrition. Mmmmm. This is the first solid food I've had in a week. 
[5]That's not the exciting part. I got my first trimester report: happy, healthy and contaminant-free... Both of us. 
[6]My baby... It's in perfect condition. I just hope I can keep it that way. I still have six months to delivery. 
[7]Why? Will you miss me? 
[8]Okay. But this is the last time. 
[9]What is it? 
[10]Don't worry. Your time will come. 
[11]Six months of mood swings, sore back and swollen feet. Want to trade places? 
[12]Lincoln? I missed you at breakfast. 
[13]I just wanted to check we're still on for tonight. The interact. 
[14]I'll see you then. Enjoy your day! 
[15]I t ' s okay. I was waiting to tell you something anyway. Guess what? 
[16]M y baby - I felt it move. And it's the weirdest feeling too. I can't explain it. It's like being more... more h e r e . 
[17]I'm sorry. I'm all excited and we're supposed to be finding peace of mind. 
[18]S o I'll see you at breakfast tomorrow? 
[19]Did I do something wrong, Lincoln? 
[20]Accept. 
[21]Lincoln ? Are you okay? I was worried. 
[22]The contamination warning. Somebody said you'd been exposed. 
[23]Is it true? Were you contaminated? 
[24]Please . . . don't come any closer. I don't want to get contaminated. 
[25]But they said... 
[26]What do you mean? 
[27]You're not making sense. 
[28]M y baby? Why would they do that? 
[29]You're scaring me, Lincoln... I want to go back now. 
[30]Don't hurt him! 
[31]Lincoln? 
[32]W h e r e did all the green go? 
[33]Is it? 
[34]I'm hungry. 
[35]P l e a s e . . . Please, I want to go back... 
[36]Lincoln , what is that? On your face? 
[37]M y throat... it feels dry... 
[38]I can't... I can't breathe... my throat... it's so... dry... 
[39]N o . . . no, it isn't... 
[40]An d then what, Lincoln? 
[41]An d then what? What if they find us? 
[42]I can't... I can't run anymore... 
[43]The Island... You mean, The Island? 
[44]Don't go yet. Stay with me, Lincoln. Stay with me for a little while. 
[45]What are you looking for? 
[46]L o o k at this... 
[47]Lincoln ! No! 
[48]The man back there... who looked like you... does it mean I have someone too? 
[49]He has marks on his face like us. 
[50]Is this... is this place The Island? 
[51]I'm tired. Let me rest for a while. 
[52]I feel better after I sleep. 
[53]I can make it. 
[54]We have to... get to... The Island... 
[55]We have to... get to... 
[56]You look tired, Lincoln. 
[57]I t ' s okay. I know. Katherine told me. 
[58]She told me a lot of things. About how they used a tiny part of her to make me. She said it wasn't so very different. 
[59]F r o m this... From having a baby. 
[60]She told me how they use us... And I keep thinking... about the others... the ones we left behind, about how they'll never know... how they'll... 
[61]I'm going to be okay, Lincoln. 
[62]I t ' s the name of his father.
dialogues.SCHEER:
[1]I forgot how much I hate the air here. 
[2]I t ' s the smell I hate. Empty. 
[3]O n e of our lab rats is missing. 
[4]D e l t a generation, huh? 
[5]I t was a Delta the last time. 
[6]What happened to this one? 
[7]N o t easy to disappear. Unless he figured a way through the boundary. 
[8]I f you ask me, it's a mistake giving them any functions at all. 
[9]The n perhaps if you're going to breed lab rats, you should breed them tame. 
[10]You mean, like fallibility? 
[11]A little sensitive, aren't we? 
[12]A l r i g h t . How much time do I have? 
[13]R e v e r s e map. Crop to twelve hour segments. Then put up a sub-grid. 
[14]S u b j e c t headed into North Quadrant. Two- m a n teams - we block him and force him to ground. If you have a shot, hook him but keep it above the belt. Management doesn't want us to "damage the product". 
[15]You want to tell me what's going on? 
[16]I'm jaded. Not stupid. 
[17]I checked up. In the past year, three products have destabilized. All of them Deltas... and there's nothing going on? 
[18]Once I can overlook. Twice I can call coincidence. Three times I start giving a shit. Because if these products are defective... 
[19]S o it is a quality control issue? 
[20]He was in the subway tunnels for two days. In the dark, no food, no water. His fingers were scraped to the bone. He was trying to dig his way out. Now you try to explain to me why that is. 
[21]So there was a production defect. 
[22]Synesthesia... 
[23]Poetic. 
[24]This "agnate" took off just before his sponsor placed an order. Maybe he got the sense his days were numbered... 
[25]Don't you mean my complicity? 
[26]What's your point? 
[27]Nobody else would take it. 
[28]Somebody get someone down here! 
[29]Ethercon! The elevator - override it! Do you read me? Bring it back down! 
[30]Foundation Levels - all of them. Lock them down. Access only on my command. 
[31]They can't have got past this level. 
[32]G e t me a bird! 
[33]The y got out! They got past the gate! 
[34]Anything? 
[35]Which one of you is Diggs? 
[36]What happened to his arm? 
[37]You don't look like bounty hunters. 
[38]I'm just an intermediary. 
[39]I was told you also handled civil bonds. Debt runners, data-thieves... 
[40]It's worth ten platinum. Unmarked. 
[41]The parties I represent want to limit the specific details. But let's just say industrial secrets are involved. 
[42]Any good at keeping them? 
[43]All I'm authorized to tell you is they have no records in this state. Also that they're not armed or dangerous. 
[44]John and Jane Doe... 
[45]Because you won't have to look. They jumped an overnight shuttle. They'll be headed for the terminal, trying to get out of state. It's strictly a recovery job. For you, it should be childsplay. 
[46]The parties I represent want to stay at arm's length. And just so we understand each other that means no connection, no papertrail, no police interest... 
[47]. . . no mistakes. They want these two brought in quickly and quietly and unharmed. Once you have them, you'll contact me for further instructions. 
[48]I told you we shouldn't have gone to outside personnel. They were cowboys. 
[49]An d now? 
[50]What's this? 
[51]A parachute... So there's a jump? 
[52]You want to dispose of your products. 
[53]Why do you think I still wear this? 
[54]I was discharged from the marines for insubordination. If you asked anyone i n my unit, they'd call it heroism. I disobeyed an order to fall back. I took out a bunker complex single-handed. 
[55]N o . It wasn't bravery. I wasn't afraid of dying. I just didn't care. You see, I suddenly realized I was just a sack of flesh with a heartbeat. Life, death, I just couldn't see the point anymore. 
[56]I'm from the Sanger Institute. 
[57]I t ' s just a formality. I need to see your sponsorship contract. 
[58]Is this the only copy? 
[59]I'm jealous of you. You have a reason to live. I can't say I've ever had that...
dialogues.DIGGS:
[1]That's me, slick. This here's my partner Burdon. Don't mind him. He gets a little shy around strangers. 
[2]`Pursuit last week. The guy took a swing at him with a fireaxe. Didn't stop Burdie though . `Took down that fucker with one arm, didn't you? 
[3]Well we're on the job, see? And it kind of helps if you bleed in. You don't look like a bondman either. 
[4]Now that's what people use when they don't want to get their hands dirty. 
[5]What we hunt depends on the bounty. 
[6]What's the bond? 
[7]Ten platinum. Must be big secrets. 
[8]Oh, me and Burdie, we're busy bees. We don't have time to file every report and we got real bad memories. But just so we understand each other, slick, we're talking about a bag job, right? 
[9]What's up with these tattoos? They look like fucking boondock types . 
[10]How about we start with their names? 
[11]You're kidding me, right? No names? 
[12]The n - with all due respect - how the fuck d o you expect us to find them? 
[13]The n why not do it yourself? Or is the dog ring just to impress the ladies? 
[14]Is that everything? 
[15]I don't know. What do you say, Burdie? 
[16]Don't bother. He'll drop by himself. 
[17]N o w . . . where were we? 
[18]H o l o s e r v e . C h e a p e r than flesh and blood but nothing between the ears. 
[19]F i r s t time I used one of these, I asked her out on a date... 
[20]J u s t wanted to help, that's all. 
[21]Why the fuck d i d n ' t you go after them?! 
[22]Fuck! 
[23]S u n n a v a b i t c h ! What the fuck d o we do now, huh? They could be anywhere... 
[24]A s what? John and Jane Doe? 
[25]Y e a h , let's tell him we couldn't hack it in kindergarten. See how long him and his ten platinum stick around. 
[26]What? 
[27]J a n e e n , where the fuck have you been? 
[28]O h , Jesus... Listen, I want you to punch into the currency stream for me. Sweep for blue card transactions. 
[29]I want serial numbers, batched a n d cross-referenced. Start from Union Station and work your way out... 
[30]We got a positive on the serial number. Punch in and pull up the transactions. Start with the last hour and work back. 
[31]I t ' s a platinum bond, Janeen. We get this, I'll buy you a new ass, okay? 
[32]Bond recovery... state license. 
[33]Play nice, little girl. Now you want to tell me where your boyfriend is? 
[34]What? 
[35]I'm a bond agent! 
[36]Punch into the currency stream, close the net on downtown and keep the search active. The next time they use the card, I want to be right on top of them... 
[37]Y e a h , well we ain't in the market. 
[38]We ' r e chasing up a currency record from last night. These two ring a bell? 
[39]Did he give you a name? 
[40]Did he say where he was going? 
[41]I got thermals. 
[42]I'm looking for two bond runners. They ditched near here last night. 
[43]One man, one woman. Tattoos on the forehead... Anyone's seen them, I got fifty green. What the fuck are you? Deaf and dumb? 
[44]Somebody start talking. 
[45]Up there in the rocks. Three o'clock. I'm not sure... it could be ambient. 
[46]Burdie...?
dialogues.CROWNE:
[1]Good morning, gentlemen. 
[2]Well when Henry called me I got the sense it wasn't for a social visit. 
[3]I understand there was an incident? 
[4]We're on the same team, Mr. Merrick. Just give me the facts down-and-dirty. 
[5]How exactly did this happen? 
[6]Do we expect more products to escape? 
[7]I'm sorry, Henry, but you asked me here to assess our liabilities. 
[8]Containment is one of the terms of our state health license. The fact it was compromised could put us in violation. 
[9]
[10]
[11]
[12]
[13]
[14]
[15]Let's take the drastic case. What then? 
[16]We haven't even touched on the worst. If these products reach a populated area, there's the problem of scrutiny. 
[17]We slipped through a loophole in the clone laws, Henry. And they only let u s through because they smelt money. And they gave us a government basement to cover their own a s s e s not ours. It's at the core of our license - why we screen potential sponsors, why we make them sign discretion agreements, why containment is such a critical factor - to limit the extent of public scrutiny. 
[18]Something to add, Mr. Merrick? 
[19]Gentlemen, whatever happens we need t o keep one thing clearly in mind. As far as the world at large goes, we are just another medical services company. Anything that alters that perception puts us at risk. And we cannot rely on the sanction of the law to protect us. Whenever and wherever and in whatever condition we recover these products, we have to stay beyond reproach. All it takes is one nudge to put us in the spotlight. Then you'll see how fast politicians can run for cover. 
[20]I take it you've heard the news. 
[21]Unfortunate? We're way past unfortunate, Henry. 
[22]The police won't connect the bond agents to us. But that's not the problem. It's the sponsor. 
[23]His name's Thomas Lincoln. It seems they had a genetic reunion. Not a h a p p y one. It was all I could do to stop him going to the authorities. 
[24]He may not want a police involvement but he's already threatened to file suit. And he's one of the biggest litigation attorneys in the city. 
[25]That's why I asked Bernard to come out here. To find out how it happened. 
[26]That's not the point. Whether or not it's a factor in this instance, it puts us in breach of the clone laws. 
[27]I'm talking about self-awareness. The virtual humanity statutes require us t o give them consciousness to the l e v e l of functionality. But not beyond. 
[28]L e g a l l y , we are naked on every level. Federal legislature, state licensing, sponsorship contract... But even if we did manage to weather the legal storm, we'd never survive the public scrutiny. 
[29]You remember cryogenics? At the outset, people dismissed it as a rich man's folly. Eccentric millionaires freezing their brains, hoping to wake up in a new body. 
[30]E v e n when cloning showed signs of m a k i n g it feasible, it wasn't moral a f f r o n t that caused the backlash. It w a s the scope. The scope, Henry. When t h e size of the customer base was e x p o s e d , it screamed inequality - one m e d i c i n e for the rich and one for the p o o r . The pressure for accessible cryo- genics a s good as buried the industry. O u r graves are being dug as we speak, g e n t l e m e n . Every passing second, they g e t deeper. If we're going to survive, w e have to act swiftly and decisively. 
[31]O u r security chief - I've been looking at his file. Ex-marine, served in South China - do we think he still has it in him? 
[32]` You ever wondered why Henry takes those pills, Bernard? Why he doesn't avail himself of his own technology? 
[33]B u l l s h i t , Henry. Bullshit. You don't want to deal with reality. Only with concept. I may not have been there at the start but I heard the stories. You wanted in on every aspect of construction, from environmental design right down to the classical playlists. I t wasn't enough just to make it work, was it? No, you wanted your own little utopia. 
[34]Swanning a r o u n d in your mountain r e t r e a t like some self-appointed d e i t y . But when it comes to getting y o u r hands dirty... 
[35]E v e n God has blood on his hands, Henry. Are you going to watch it all go up in flames or are you going to deal with it? 
[36]What's your point? 
[37]M r s . Ester? My name is Ellen Crowne. 
[38]L e g a l issues must seem trivial at this time. But the sponsorship agreement has certain conditions relating to confident- i a l i t y . D e s p i t e this tragic t u r n of events, those conditions remain binding. We want to be sure you understand that. 
[39]T h a t said, The Institute is likewise bound by the terms of sponsorship and while we reserve every right... 
[40]L e g a l l y , human rights don't apply. 
[41]We do have other issues to discuss... 
[42]We l l , I don't know about the two of you but I'd say we got off lightly. 
[43]Don't start getting maudlin, Henry. It's a little too late in the game.
dialogues.KATHERINE:
[1]O h , God... Oh, my God... 
[2]J u s t something to help her sleep. I think she has a bronchial infection. But I'm not sure I should give her an antibiotic in case it effects the baby. 
[3]Is n ' t that why you came here? 
[4]The y have a plan... For women like me. 
[5]You know when you're young? How you run around thinking you're immortal? 
[6]The r e was a lodeway accident. I was... damaged. After that, I thought no man would ever want me. I was wrong. His name was John. He said he married me for my eyes. Ocean eyes, he called them. He always loved the ocean. Up there on the wall, that's John's boat. 
[7]But I think there was always an unspoken regret between us. When we heard about the technology, it was like... forgive- n e s s , like a second chance. A child of our own, part of both of us. Sailing trips, fishing trips, so many plans... J o h n got cancer a year ago. He died. 
[8]I r o n i c . That the same technology could have saved his life. And now the baby is the only part of him I have left. And the boat. I still have the boat. 
[9]What do I call you? 
[10]Lincoln , I think she needs professional help. I think she needs to see a doctor. 
[11]N o t if I don't want them to. 
[12]The doctor I'm thinking of, he's an old friend. He look after John in t h e final stages. I trust him. 
[13]N o . No, that's not what I want. 
[14]M a y b e I didn't realize she'd      be so... M a y b e I just didn't want to.      Either way, I was wrong. I want you          to know that. I was wrong... And I'm          sorry. 
[15]E v e n if I had taken her baby, I swear to you, I'd never have... They give you a choice, you see, to extend the sponsorship after... after d e l i v e r y . 
[16]You mean... Even if I had extended the sponsorship, they'd have... and kept taking the money? But that's inhuman. 
[17]We l l I've been keeping busy. Trying to. Thanks for coming down to meet me. 
[18]I t ' s not me... Not exactly. 
[19]He means that by trying to help her, we could lose her. Or lose the baby. 
[20]What are you talking about? 
[21]I see. 
[22]You can stop there. I know why I'm here. You wanted to know if I'm going to sue you for breach of contract. 
[23]I don't want restitution, Dr. Sanger. The reason I agreed to this meeting was to have the chance to talk to you. 
[24]I never got to meet you when I visited The Institute. It was one of your sales- m e n who led the tour. I remember how h e described the agnates a s if they were some kind of mindless organisms. More like livestock than humanity... 
[25]I remember how eager I was to believe him. But when I saw w h a t I'd created, in flesh and blood, when I touched h e r , it was I who felt less than human. 
[26]Ester ' s life was my responsibility and her death is my cross to bear alone. So I'm not going to sue you, Dr. Sanger... But I am going to blame y o u . Until the day I die, I will silently curse your name. That's w h a t I wanted you to know. 
[27]An d now I'd like to leave, please. 
[28]I don't think they suspected anything. 
[29]I know... But it felt good. It felt like something John would have done. 
[30]Yes . There are people sympathetic to the cause. I'm going to get it to them. 
[31]Don't forget that. It has the operating manuals for the boat. 
[32]But the maps, the charts...
dialogues.TOM:
[1]Oh, Jesus... 
[2]The y said... I'd never have to see you. 
[3]The people... 
[4]Look, if you don't get out of here right now, I'm calling security... 
[5]Why are you here? What do you want? 
[6]One of the partners at my firm... he told me about it. Gave me a referral. I thought he was joking at first. I went out there, took the sales tour. Even before that I knew it wasn't a joke. There was this discretion agree- ment. I never saw anything like it and I've seen a lot. Ironclad... breathe a word and they've got you by the balls. I don't know... There's cancer in my family. Maybe it was just to keep up. All the partners were on the policy. 
[7]Christ, you have no idea, do you? 
[8]I can't fucking do this... 
[9]Insurance. You're an insurance policy. 
[10]Health insurance... medical... 
[11]If I get sick... if part of me gets sick... I take a healthy part from you. 
[12]How do you expect me to answer that? It's just how it works, that's all. 
[13]What do you want? A fucking apology? 
[14]Because you are me . . . 
[15]Because they made you from my cells... 
[16]That's right. You were made. Cooked up in a centrifuge like a fucking boiled egg. Every thought running through your head, every word coming out of your mouth, all of it, manufactured, made... 
[17]No. 
[18]I signed a contract. I can show you. 
[19]It's all right there. Who, why... 
[20]Look you've got what you wanted. Now why don't you just get out of here? 
[21]I can't... 
[22]I can't. Look, I'm a lawyer, I know how it works. The contract, everything, it's all laced with confidentiality clauses. It means they don't want this to get out. It means whatever I do, they're not going to stop. You understand? 
[23]Transport , yes... yes, parked downstairs... Bay 53... Take it... 
[24]I'm not going to call security. I'm not going to call anybody, okay? 
[25]Look, maybe there's something... maybe there's a way to cancel the contract... 
[26]For Christ's sake! It's not my fault! 
[27]Yes? 
[28]I've given you people enough of my time already. 
[29]Why would I make copies? Do you think I want anyone else to know about this?
dialogues.JONES:
[1]You know that guy who won the Spin in your sector? Starkweather? 
[2]I had a bout with him last week. Guess how long he's been here? Six months. 
[3]You don't believe me - look it up. 
[4]What do you say now? Still think The Spin's rigged for the long haulers? 
[5]And don't you wish it was you... out there on The Island... nature's own clean air zone... no screening, no quotas... unlimited pleasure... 
[6]Why don't you make me? In the ring. 
[7]Not anymore. They just got the new program in - multi-weight balancing. 
[8]C'mon, champ. A stim unit says you won't last three rounds. 
[9]Sure you input the right weight class? 
[10]You're faster `cause you're lighter. Programmers... they always miss something. 
[11]So make it a beer and a Vita Cola. 
[12]You know, you're going to get yourself contaminated one of these days. 
[13]So, you up for a rematch tomorrow? 
[14]With who? That blonde again? 
[15]You want to get flagged for proximity? 
[16]Quick . . . Give me that beer back. 
[17]What's going on, officer? 
[18]So? 
[19]Maybe the system didn't update yet. 
[20]What? You think he's still here? The guy wins a place on The Island and you think he just decided not to go? 
[21]And now nothing. It's probably the programmers messing up. 
[22]A stim unit says I can prove it. Cross reference with sanitation. 
[23]See ? Standard procedure. They got to sweep it for the next occupant. 
[24]Hey, champ. Are you alright? I heard there was a contamination scare. 
[25]What are you talking about? 
[26]You caught that fucking p a t h o g e n , didn't you? You're contaminated.
dialogues.OZZIE:
[1]Hello? 
[2]Can I help you? 
[3]Got stuck in that supercell, didya? 
[4]Supercellstorm , that's what they call it on the news anyways. I n my day, we just called `em "big ol' h o w l e r s " . 
[5]Yep, I heard it shut down some of the lodeways. Dust in the works, I guess. Where were you folks headed anyways? 
[6]A w a y ? You mean, like outta s t a t e ? 
[7]N o w where's my manners gone? I'm Ozzie. Osmund r e a l l y . But folks call me Ozzie. 
[8]S o m e t i m e s I like to make a joke of it, my last name bein' D e e r . . . "O. Deer". 
[9]We l l now, looks like yer g i r l f r i e n d ' s made herself at home. 
[10]Yer girlfriend sure is pretty. 
[11]So what's with them tattoos, huh? 
[12]Hey , in the eye of the beholder, right? Now this place, this is beautiful to me. This is my place. I own it. `May not look like much but you'd be surprised. C'mon, lemme show you... 
[13]M o s t a t h i s heavy stuff's industrial scrap. Comes in from all over. Easy way round the recyclin' l a w s . Me, I sell it on to the boondock b o y s for meltdown. Other stuff, I pick up at the scrap markets. Fix it up, `fetches a price. 
[14]Fossil fuel transport. This piece o' junk's a collector's item. All that Age of the Wheel nostalgia, "elegant era of transport" bullshit. I find the parts, she's as good as solid gold. 
[15]Now this here's got a colorful history. Came in from this ol' g o v e r n m e n t bunker out in the valley. `Got shut down way back. Then this new outfit took over, stripped the place out. I guess they're doin' s o m e more remodelling cause I just had `em in again the other day... Hump`n dump crew. Nice fellas. 
[16]You okay there? 
[17]Nuthin . I wasn't doin nuthin . 
[18]I knew it... them clothes... them weird tattoos... I mean, I heard stories from those guys but I never... 
[19]N o t that I believe `em... buncha c r a z y stories... nuthin t o do with you... 
[20]W h a d d y a s a y we just forget about it, huh? How about I go getcha a beer? 
[21]What e v e r you want... Just take it... Whaddya w a n t . . . ? You want money...? 
[22]I t ' s all I got... Take it... just please... just don't hurt me...
dialogues.MCCORD:
[1]Sorry, chief. I can't let you get any closer. We got live wires over there. 
[2]What's that you said? 
[3]He y , you get yourself contaminated, don't come pointing the finger at me. 
[4]You know how it is. `Gets to the end of shift, `crew starts draggin t h e i r feet. 
[5]I guess if we bust our backs, we could be out of here by the end of the week. 
[6]Thanks , chief. I appreciate that. 
[7]What do you mean? 
[8]You mean, these things? Well, these things ain't good for you anyways. 
[9]That's because we ain't supposed to. They got rules about fraternization. 
[10]M o r e of the same. They cycle us onto the disposal detail. Hump `n dump crew. 
[11]D e b r i s clearance. We hump the heavy stuff to a site on the outside. 
[12]Right. 
[13]I don't know too much about that. 
[14]He y , take it from me, you got a sweet deal right here. So why worry, huh?
dialogues.CENSOR:
[1]You asshole! You hooked the wrong one! 
[2]J u s t a flesh wound. `Hit his head pretty hard. Possible concussion. T h i n k you can walk, buddy? 
[3]You see this? It'll get you past the lockdown. You're to report to The Medical Center. You understand? 
[4]Yeah, no sweat, subject is secured. 
[5]Nothing , sir. No sign. 
[6]A bird?! In this storm?! 
[7]Ground team checking in. 
[8]The storm pretty much covered their tracks. We're scanning for thermals b u t the hotter it gets, the harder it is to isolate a heat signature. I don't know, sir, it's a big desert out there. 
[9]S i r , I've been trying to contact you. It's the ether... Something's wrong. We l l , Starkweather, if you're watching on etherscreen - your time has come, my friend! You're going to The Island! 
[10]That's what I mean. We can't get through. The circuits are locked. 
[11]C o m m u n i t y - w i d e , sir. Everywhere.
dialogues.BURDON:
[1]F r a n k Hofstetter! This is a bond recovery! Step away from the bar! 
[2]You folks need a ride? 
[3]P r i v a t e cab. No state surcharge... 
[4]Shit! 
[5]We go back to the office and run `em. 
[6]We ask the guy. 
[7]I t was blue, right? 
[8]The y were using a blue currency card. 
[9]G o ahead. I'll look after her. 
[10]Diggs! Get me outta here! 
[11]Help me! HELP MEEEEE!
dialogues.LYDIA:
[1]L a d i e s and gentlemen, my name is Lydia and on behalf of our staff, I'd like t o welcome you to The Sanger Institute. 
[2]Before we start the tour, we'll be serv- i n g r e f r e s h m e n t s in the visitor center and circulating our standard discretion agreements. I should add that today you are all very lucky because our CEO and founder, Dr. Henry Sanger, is with us and will be leading the tour personally. 
[3]T o d a y ' s group is from New Gaza Health Care. They're with the platinum plan. 
[4]This month we're offering a special rate for new sponsors. Including a 10% discount on the his-and-hers plan. 
[5]DR. SANGER? Would you like to close? 
[6]L a d i e s and gentlemen, my name is Lydia and on behalf of our staff, I'd like t o welcome you to The Sanger Institute. Before we start the tour, we'll be serv- i n g r e f r e s h m e n t s in the visitor center and circulating our standard discretion agreements. I should add that today you are all very lucky because our CEO and founder, Dr. Henry Sanger, is with us and will be leading the tour personally. 
[7]Yes . . . Mr. Thomas, isn't it? 
[8]We l l we're about to start the tour. But I can have someone check for you. 
[9]
[10]He's having a heart attack! A doctor! Somebody get a doctor in here!
dialogues.THE SNAKE:
[1]H i there! I'm Tattletail! What e v e r you want to know, wherever you want to go, I got the answers! Let's look at the menu! 
[2]N o w let's make a selection! 
[3]O k a y ! Let me open that directory for you! I'll be with you in two shakes! 
[4]Hi there! I'm Tattletail! What e v e r you want to know, wherever you want to go, I got the answers! Let's look at the menu! 
[5]N o w let's make a selection! 
[6]Please give me the name. 
[7]Okay! Let me find that listing for you! I'll be with you in two shakes! 
[8]Starkweather , Jamil... I'm sorry! This listing is blocked from the directory! 
[9]You want me to find another listing?
dialogues.GREY DOVE:
[1]Or did you come here for a reason? 
[2]Not the best place to look. 
[3]I see. And where were you going? 
[4]It is a sacred place. My people come here to commune with their spirits. 
[5]Not easy to understand perhaps. For us, the spirit is like the shadow on the rock. Sometimes close, sometimes far away, sometimes the sky clouds and the shadow fades. We come here to ask our spirits to return to us. The man... He speaks to The Grandfather from whom all spirits are born. The Great Spirit who binds every living thing. He has no name. But he is everywhere. In the sun and the moon, the wind and the rain... 
[6]Now he asks for the gift of vision that he may see through to the spirit shape of things. To find the spirits of the lost. To bring them into the light...
